docs.lead_paragraph: The self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry. After all, if you don’t lose those pounds or stop smoking this year, you’ll probably try again in 2013.

headline.seo: New Year’s Resolutions, Recycled, Are a Boon for Business
headline.main: Your Recycled Resolutions Are a Boon for Business
headline.print_headline: I Just Got Here, But I Know Trouble When I See It: Those Recycled Resolutions Are a Boon for Business

docs.abstract: Self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry; Americans were projected to spend $62 billion in 2011 on self-improvement in the hope of keeping resolutions; some stop-smoking and weight-loss programs, as well as gyms, are trying to help for the long haul, a strategy that can improve customers' chances of success and build brand loyalty and revenue.
docs.snippet: The self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry. After all, if you don’t lose those pounds or stop smoking this year, you’ll probably try again in 2013.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many on-site cafes, geared to serve fitness-conscious exercisers with choices like vegetarian and gluten-free cuisine, are open to nonmembers, too.

headline.seo: Cafes at Health Clubs Stress Eating Right
headline.main: At the Gym Site, Food for Fitness Lovers
headline.kicker: New Jersey Dining | Health Club Cafes
headline.print_headline: At the Gym Site, Food For Fitness Lovers
headline.content_kicker: New Jersey Dining | Health Club Cafes

docs.abstract: Kelly Feeney reviews restaurants located at several health clubs in New Jersey.
docs.snippet: Many on-site cafes, geared to serve fitness-conscious exercisers with choices like vegetarian and gluten-free cuisine, are open to nonmembers, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope article highlights research done by University of Melbourne professor Dr Joseph Proietto on obesity, which was published in The New England Journal of Medicine and has caused a stir in the weight-loss community; Proietto and his colleagues have found that the human body continues to fight against weight loss long after dieting has stopped, and adds to a growing body of evidence that challenges conventional thinking about obesity.
docs.snippet: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
